"newrepublic.com", "text": "\nOff Leash was still active as of Wednesday, though I expect it won\u2019t be, at least in its current form, for much longer, given that the conversation Wednesday included much discussion about their security being breached, which became evident after I reached out to participants for comment. Fortunately, I obtained details about a large slice of the chat group\u2019s discussions over the past six months. Here\u2019s some of what they discussed.\n\nSolving the Middle East Crisis: Nukes, Napalm, and Other \u201cExtreme Measures\u201d\n\nOff Leash was launched less than two months after Israel commenced its assault on Gaza following Hamas\u2019s deadly October 7 attack on Israel, and that topic has been one of the group chat\u2019s main concerns since it was established by Prince on December 2. Five days later, Omer Laviv, an executive with the Mer Group, a private security company with many former Israeli intelligence officials in its senior ranks, posted \u301016\u2020a story\u2020www.thetimes.co.uk\u3011 to the group that ran two days earlier in The Times of London and reported Prince had been seeking to sell the Israel Defense Forces equipment for a plan he\u2019d devised to flood Hamas tunnels with seawater.\n\n\u201cI was involved,\u201d remarked Moti Kahana, the Israeli American businessman who runs GDC, the firm where Off Leash member Stuart Seldowitz previously worked. Kahana pointedly added that at least one part of The Times\u2019 story was false\u2014for example, Prince had offered to donate the equipment, not sell it, he said.\n\n\u201cWhy do you expect accuracy from journalists?\u201d retorted Laviv, who during the Trump administration retained 27 U.S. lobbyists and consultants to run a $9.5 million lobbying campaign on behalf of President Joseph Kabila, the corrupt, brutal leader of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who used surveillance equipment supplied by the Mer Group to monitor his regime\u2019s opponents. Among those Laviv involved were Rudy Giuliani, Trump\u2019s former personal lawyer, fixer, and dirt-digger, and Robert Stryk, whose clients have included Saudi Arabia and El Salvador\u2019s state intelligence agency under crypto-fascist President Nayib Bukele.\n\nYudelson, who also reportedly partnered with Prince in an attempt to buy weapons for resale from Belarus dictator Aleksandr Lukashenko (\u301017\u2020whom the two men praised for bringing \u201cpeace, stability, and prosperity to your country\u2020matthewcole.substack.com\u3011\u201d), predicted the tunnel-flooding proposal would be shot down by the \u201cIsraeli left,\u201d a force he labeled the country\u2019s \u201cbiggest enemy,\u201d ahead of Hamas and Iran, over concerns about the environmental impact in Gaza. \u201cWho gives a shit about that,\u201d Yudelson posted to the group. \u201cIf it was up to me \u2026 I would flood them with Napalm! I would burn all those bastards, and have everything above ground, everything left of Gaza, collapse into this fiery hell pit and burn!\u201d\n\nEven that was deemed to be insufficiently hawkish for some Off Leash participants. In a lengthy tirade on February 14, Tzvi Lev, who formerly worked in Israel\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said it was rare to see a people as \u201ctwisted\u201d as Palestinians, whose culture \u201cworships death and bloodshed.\u201d The only solution, he wrote, was to \u201ccompletely uproot the radical Islamic Palestinian nationalism,\u201d which was possible to do based on the historical precedent of Japan, which \u201cwent from being nuked twice to one of the world\u2019s strongest economies within two decades.\u201d Dropping nuclear weapons on what\u2019s left of densely populated Gaza, which is roughly the size of Detroit, would be a war crime and kill huge numbers of civilians.\n\nYoav Goldhorn, \u301018\u2020the former Israeli intelligence officer\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, also cited \u201cfucking nukes in Japan\u201d as an appropriate remedy to the Palestinian problem. Sadly, wrote Goldhorn, whose LinkedIn profile says he has \u201ca passion for strategic planning,\u201d there was no one in the Israeli government with \u201cthe balls nor vision to go all those extra miles.\u201d\n\nIran: Off Leash\u2019s Public Enemy No. 1 \n\nIt was hard to keep track of all the wars, invasions, covert operations, coups, and assassinations Off Leash members favored. One region ripe for a bit of good old-fashioned Western intervention was Africa, which was described as a \u201cpot about to boil over\u201d by \u301019\u2020Emma Priestley\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011, who posts as \u201cCustomer\u201d in the group chat and is the \u301019\u2020CEO of GoldStone Resources Limited\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011 in Jersey, the English Channel island that is one of the world\u2019s most popular offshore secrecy havens. China would have to be taken down a peg as well, particularly as Biden wasn\u2019t going to stop the country \u201cfrom doing a damn thing,\u201d and indeed he would pave the way for it to do \u201cwhatever it is they want to accomplish,\u201d posted Randy Couture, the former UFC heavyweight champion and actor who had the role of arsonist and killer Jason Duclair in the TV series Hawaii Five-0 and starred in the 2011 movie Setup with 50 Cent and Bruce Willis.\n\nBut the No. 1 target on Off Leash\u2019s hit list, by orders of magnitude, was Iran. \u201cFollow the source of evil,\u201d wrote Montana Congressman Ryan Zinke, who served as interior secretary under Trump. \u201cHamas. Hezbollah. Houthis. Iran is the center of gravity.\u201d\n\n\u201cZinke is right,\u201d agreed Tennessee Congressman Mark Green of the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nYemen\u2019s Houthi rebels", "title": "Off Leash: Inside the Secret, Global, Far-Right Group Chat   | The New Republic", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Off Leash: Inside the Secret, Global, Far-Right Group Chat   | The New Republic", "url": "https://newrepublic.com/article/182008/erik-prince-secret-global-group-chat-off-leash", "text": "\nOff Leash was still active as of Wednesday, though I expect it won\u2019t be, at least in its current form, for much longer, given that the conversation Wednesday included much discussion about their security being breached, which became evident after I reached out to participants for comment. Reserved.\n\n\u30101\u2020Home\u3011\n\n/\n\n\u301022\u2020World\u3011\n\n# Erik Prince says China likely to attack Taiwan in 2024 \n\nXi Jinping must feel &#x27;door is wide open&#x27; amid declining US credibility under Biden administration, says former Blackwater chair \n\nDec. 31, 2023 16:58\n\n[Image 21: Erik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) ]\n\nErik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) \n\n38154 \n\nTAIPEI (Taiwan News) \u2014 In a video interview on the U.K.\u2019s GB News filmed on Thursday (Dec. 28), Erik Prince, a military contractor known for founding the Blackwater organization, said he expects China to target Taiwan militarily in the spring of 2024.\n\nPrince, a military strategist and former U.S. Navy Seal, was being \u301027\u2020interviewed\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011 by Jacob Rees-Mogg about U.S. foreign policy setbacks under the Biden administration and the pressures faced by the U.S. military around the world. Prince said that amid declining U.S. credibility abroad, Chinese leader Xi Jinping (\u7fd2\u8fd1\u5e73) may try to \u201cbluster his way\u201d into a takeover of Taiwan, saying that \u201cit must feel like the door is wide open for them to do whatever it is they want to do.\u201d\n\nPrince\u2019s comments came one day after Xi Jinping, speaking at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, resolutely vowed to stop anyone from \u201cmaking Taiwan secede from China,\u201d calling \u301028\u2020unification\u3011 an \u201cinevitable trend.\u201d\n\nIn Prince\u2019s remarks, he criticized the U.S. \u201cinability to finish properly in Iraq and Afghanistan,\u201d which he credits for the increase of military threats across the world that have taken shape under the Biden administration. In addition to ongoing conflicts involving Ukraine and Israel, Prince also mentioned escalating conflicts in the wider Middle East, which now include attacks by Houthi rebels targeting shipping vessels in the Red Sea.\n\nSpeaking about a timeline for a potential attack by China on Taiwan, Prince said May or June 2024 is a likely window for Beijing to begin cross-strait naval operations. &quot;If they are going to take Taiwan by force, I would predict that they are going to do something this spring,&quot; Prince said, as reported by \u301029\u2020GB News\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011.\n\nThe day after Prince made his prediction on GB News, China announced a shakeup in its military command. With only two weeks before Taiwan&#x27;s elections, Beijing appointed PLAN \u301030\u2020Admiral Dong Jun\u3011 as its newest Minister of National Defense.\n\nAfter leaving Blackwater and selling the company in 2010, Erik Prince\u2019s connections to CIA training programs were revealed in 2013. Around 2014, Prince became the chairman of a private security and logistics firm called the Frontier Services Group, a Chinese-owned company based in Hong Kong and involved in private security contract work in Africa.\n\nPrince stepped down as chairman of the Frontier Services Group in April 2021 but is still the head of a similar organization called the Frontier Resource Group, which has almost no online footprint as of publication.\n\n\u301031\u2020# Chinese invasion of Taiwan\u3011\u301032\u2020# Biden Administration\u3011\u301033\u2020# Erik Prince\u3011\u301034\u2020# Xi Reserved.\n\n\u30101\u2020Home\u3011\n\n/\n\n\u301022\u2020World\u3011\n\n# Erik Prince says China likely to attack Taiwan in 2024 \n\nXi Jinping must feel &#x27;door is wide open&#x27; amid declining US credibility under Biden administration, says former Blackwater chair \n\nDec. 31, 2023 16:58\n\n[Image 21: Erik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) ]\n\nErik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) \n\n38154 \n\nTAIPEI (Taiwan News) \u2014 In a video interview on the U.K.\u2019s GB News filmed on Thursday (Dec. 28), Erik Prince, a military contractor known for founding the Blackwater organization, said he expects China to target Taiwan militarily in the spring of 2024.\n\nPrince, a military strategist and former U.S. Navy Seal, was being \u301027\u2020interviewed\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011 by Jacob Rees-Mogg about U.S. foreign policy setbacks under the Biden administration and the pressures faced by the U.S. military around the world. Prince said that amid declining U.S. credibility abroad, Chinese leader Xi Jinping (\u7fd2\u8fd1\u5e73) may try to \u201cbluster his way\u201d into a takeover of Taiwan, saying that \u201cit must feel like the door is wide open for them to do whatever it is they want to do.\u201d\n\nPrince\u2019s comments came one day after Xi Jinping, speaking at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, resolutely vowed to stop anyone from \u201cmaking Taiwan secede from China,\u201d calling \u301028\u2020unification\u3011 an \u201cinevitable trend.\u201d\n\nIn Prince\u2019s remarks, he criticized the U.S. \u201cinability to finish properly in Iraq and Afghanistan,\u201d which he credits for the increase of military threats across the world that have taken shape under the Biden administration. In addition to ongoing conflicts involving Ukraine and Israel, Prince also mentioned escalating conflicts in the wider Middle East, which now include attacks by Houthi rebels targeting shipping vessels in the Red Sea.\n\nSpeaking about a timeline for a potential attack by China on Taiwan, Prince said May or June 2024 is a likely window for Beijing to begin cross-strait naval operations. &quot;If they are going to take Taiwan by force, I would predict that they are going to do something this spring,&quot; Prince said, as reported by \u301029\u2020GB News\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011.\n\nThe day after Prince made his prediction on GB News, China announced a shakeup in its military command. With only two weeks before Taiwan&#x27;s elections, Beijing appointed PLAN \u301030\u2020Admiral Dong Jun\u3011 as its newest Minister of National Defense.\n\nAfter leaving Blackwater and selling the company in 2010, Erik Prince\u2019s connections to CIA training programs were revealed in 2013. Around 2014, Prince became the chairman of a private security and logistics firm called the Frontier Services Group, a Chinese-owned company based in Hong Kong and involved in private security contract work in Africa.\n\nPrince stepped down as chairman of the Frontier Services Group in April 2021 but is still the head of a similar organization called the Frontier Resource Group, which has almost no online footprint as of publication.\n\n\u301031\u2020# Chinese invasion of Taiwan\u3011\u301032\u2020# Biden Administration\u3011\u301033\u2020# Erik Prince\u3011\u301034\u2020# Xi Jinping\u3011\n\n# Related Articles\n\n* * *\n\n\u301035\u2020Ex-Australia PM calls for effective deterrent against China\u2019s threats to annex Taiwan Oct. 22, 2024 14:56\u3011\u301036\u2020Harris says Taiwan &#x27;has right to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 17, 2024 10:41\u3011\u301037\u2020Trump claims China will not invade Taiwan if he is elected Oct. 16, 2024 16:43\u3011\u301038\u2020Former AIT chair says Article 8 of China\u2019s Anti-Secession Law is time bomb Oct. 16, 2024 13:43\u3011\u301039\u2020Poll shows 36% of Americans support sending troops to defend Taiwan Oct. 9, 2024 16:26\u3011\u301040\u2020Harris backs &#x27;Taiwan&#x27;s ability to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 8, 2024 14:27\u3011\n\n# MOST READ\n\n* * *\n\n\u301041\u2020Harvard punishes Taiwanese American student for disrupting Chinese ambassador\u3011\u301042\u2020Tropical Storm Trami forecast to steer south of Taiwan\u3011\u301043\u2020Tropi", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[8, 2, 7, 9, 12]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "c08fd06c-fd91-4038-b6ac-5dfd6a849246", "request_id": "8d71cd7a39500dfa-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "c08fd06c-fd91-4038-b6ac-5dfd6a849246", "children": ["4678175a-6ced-49e9-8a45-f05ed4ccce02"]}, "4678175a-6ced-49e9-8a45-f05ed4ccce02": { "message": { "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729687319.012538, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Prince", "domain": "en.wikipedia.org", "text": "\nBlackwater came under increasing criticism after the \u3010126\u2020Nisour Square massacre\u3011 in September 2007, in which Blackwater employees opened fire in a crowded square in Baghdad, killing 17 Iraqi civilians and seriously wounding 20 more. Three guards were convicted in October 2014 of 14 manslaughter charges, and another of murder, in a U.S. court in 2019.[ 24 ][ 25 ]\n\nThe criticism continued after president \u3010127\u2020Barack Obama\u3011 took office in 2009. Prince said he believes that much of this criticism stems from politics. &quot;I put myself and my company at the CIA&#x27;s disposal for some very risky missions&quot;, Prince told \u3010128\u2020Vanity Fair\u3011 for its January 2010 issue. &quot;But when it became politically expedient to do so, someone threw me under the bus.&quot;[ 26 ] Blackwater lost a $1 billion contract with the State Department to protect American diplomatic personnel in 2009, after the Iraqi government refused to renew the company&#x27;s operating license.[ 27 ] Nevertheless, in 2010 the \u3010129\u2020Obama administration\u3011 awarded the company a $120 million \u3010130\u2020United States Department of State\u3011 security contract and about $100 million in new CIA work.[ 21 ]\n\nIn 2012 Blackwater&#x27;s successor company, Academi, paid a combined $49.5 million to settle charges of arms trafficking violations dating back to the period Prince was CEO and chairman of the company.[ 28 ] In 2020 Prince again became the focus of an FBI investigation into arms trafficking violations related to the conversion of crop dusters into military aircraft.[ 29 ] According to a UN report, Prince also violated a UN arms embargo by aiding a plot to arm a Libyan warlord attempting to overthrow the US and UN backed government in Libya.[ 30 ]\n\nPrince has defended Blackwater&#x27;s work, pointing to the fact that during the course of 40,000 personal security missions, only 200 involved guards firing their weapons. He has said, &quot;No one under our care was ever killed or injured. We kept them safe, all the while we had 30 of our men killed.&quot;[ 19 ]\n\nPrince, according to author \u3010131\u2020Robert Young Pelton\u3011, reportedly thinks of Blackwater&#x27;s relationship to the military as something similar to \u3010132\u2020FedEx\u3011&#x27;s relationship to the \u3010133\u2020U.S. Post Office\u3011: &quot;an efficient, privatized solution to sclerotic and wasteful government bureaucracy.&quot;[ 31 ] He credits his father&#x27;s competitive streak in the automotive business with the inspiration to design a lighter, faster army.[ 32 ]\n\nPrince resigned as CEO of Blackwater on March 2, 2009, and remained chairman of the board until he sold the company in late 2010 to a group of investors.[ 33 ]\n\nAs Americans and others were being evacuated following the August 2021 \u3010134\u2020collapse of the Afghan government\u3011, Prince said he was offering seats on a chartered flight for $6,500 per person.[ 34 ]\n\n### Disclosure as part of a covert CIA task force\n\n[\u3010135\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nPrince was part of a CIA task force created to engage in \u3010136\u2020targeted killings\u3011 of suspected terrorists. Prince alleged that the House intelligence congressional committee leaked his name to the press.[ 35 ] Prince has said that he is convinced that former CIA director \u3010137\u2020Leon Panetta\u3011 revealed him as a CIA asset, after shutting down the covert CIA training operation in 2009.[ 20 ]\n\n### Private security for the United Arab Emirates\n\n[\u3010138\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nAfter Blackwater faced mounting legal problems in the United States, Prince was hired by the crown prince of Abu Dhabi and moved to Abu Dhabi in 2010. His task was to assemble an 800-member group of foreign troops for the U.A.E., which was planned months before the \u3010139\u2020Arab Spring\u3011.[ 36 ] He helped the UAE found a new company named Reflex Responses, or R2, with 51 percent local ownership, carefully avoiding his name on corporate documents. He worked to oversee the effort and recruit troops, among others from \u3010140\u2020Executive Outcomes\u3011, a former South African mercenary firm hired by several African governments during the 1990s to defeat violent rebellions in addition to protecting oil and diamond reserves. \n\nAs of January 2011, Prince was training a force of 2,000 Somalis for anti-piracy operations in the Gulf of Aden. The program was funded by several Arab countries, including the \u3010141\u2020United Arab Emirates\u3011 and backed by the United States. Prince&#x27;s spokesman, \u3010142\u2020Mark Corallo\u3011, said Prince had &quot;no financial role&quot; in the project and declined to answer any questions about Prince&#x27;s involvement. John Burnett of Maritime Underwater Security Consultants said, &quot;There are 34 nations with naval assets trying to stop piracy and it can only be stopped on land. With Prince&#x27;s background and rather illustrious reputation, I think it&#x27;s quite possible that it might work.&quot;[ 37 ]\n\n### Private equity investor in Africa\n\n[\u3010143\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nPrince leads a private equity firm called Frontier Resource Group, and until April 13, 2021, he was also chairman of \u301090\u2020Frontier Services Group\u3011 Ltd, a Bermuda-incorporated logistics and transport company listed on the \u3010144\u2020Hong Kong Stock Exc", "title": "Erik Prince - Wikipedia", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Erik Prince - Wikipedia", "url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erik_Prince", "text": "\nBlackwater came under increasing criticism after the \u3010126\u2020Nisour Square massacre\u3011 in September 2007, in which Blackwater employees opened fire in a crowded square in Baghdad, killing 17 Iraqi civilians and seriously wounding 20 more. Three guards were convicted in October 2014 of 14 manslaughter charges, and another of murder, in a U.S. court in 2019.[ 24 ][ 25 ]\n\nThe criticism continued after president \u3010127\u2020Barack Obama\u3011 took office in 2009. Prince said he believes that much of this criticism stems from politics. &quot;I put myself and my company at the CIA&#x27;s disposal for some very risky missions&quot;, Prince told \u3010128\u2020Vanity Fair\u3011 for its January 2010 issue. &quot;But when it became politically expedient to do so, someone threw me under the bus.&quot;[ 26 ] Blackwater lost a $1 billion contract with the State Department to protect American diplomatic personnel in 2009, after the Iraqi government refused to renew the company&#x27;s operating license.[ 27 ] Nevertheless, in 2010 the \u3010129\u2020Obama administration\u3011 awarded the company a $120 million \u3010130\u2020United States Department of State\u3011 security contract and about $100 million in new CIA work.[ 21 ]\n\nIn 2012 Blackwater&#x27;s successor company, Academi, paid a combined $49.5 million to settle charges of arms trafficking violations dating back to the period Prince was CEO and chairman of the company.[ 28 ] In 2020 Prince again became the focus of an FBI investigation into arms trafficking violations related to the conversion of crop dusters into military aircraft.[ 29 ] According to a UN report, Prince also violated a UN arms embargo by aiding a plot to arm a Libyan warlord attempting to overthrow the US and UN backed government in Libya.[ 30 ]\n\nPrince has defended Blackwater&#x27;s work, pointing to the fact that during the course of 40,000 personal security missions, only 200 involved guards firing their weapons. He has said, &quot;No one under our care was ever killed or injured. We kept them safe, all the while we had 30 of our men killed.&quot;[ 19 ]\n\nPrince, according to author \u3010131\u2020Robert Young Pelton\u3011, reportedly thinks of Blackwater&#x27;s relationship to the military as something similar to \u3010132\u2020FedEx\u3011&#x27;s relationship to the \u3010133\u2020U.S. Post Office\u3011: &quot;an efficient, privatized solution to sclerotic and wasteful government bureaucracy.&quot;[ 31 ] He credits his father&#x27;s competitive streak in the automotive business with the inspiration to design a lighter, faster army.[ 32 ]\n\nPrince resigned as CEO of Blackwater on March 2, 2009, and remained chairman of the board until he sold the company in late 2010 to a group of investors.[ 33 ]\n\nAs Americans and others were being evacuated following the August 2021 \u3010134\u2020collapse of the Afghan government\u3011, Prince said he was offering seats on a chartered flight for $6,500 per person.[ 34 ]\n\n### Disclosure as part of a covert CIA task force\n\n[\u3010135\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nPrince was part of a CIA task force created to engage in \u3010136\u2020targeted killings\u3011 of suspected terrorists. Prince alleged that the House intelligence congressional committee leaked his name to the press.[ 35 ] Prince has said that he is convinced that former CIA director \u3010137\u2020Leon Panetta\u3011 revealed him as a CIA asset, after shutting down the covert CIA training operation in 2009.[ 20 ]\n\n### Private security for the United Arab Emirates\n\n[\u3010138\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nAfter Blackwater faced mounting legal problems in the United States, Prince was hired by the crown prince of Abu Dhabi and moved to Abu Dhabi in 2010. His task was to assemble an 800-member group of foreign troops for the U.A.E., which was planned months before the \u3010139\u2020Arab Spring\u3011.[ 36 ] He helped the UAE found a new company named Reflex Responses, or R2, with 51 percent local ownership, carefully avoiding his name on corporate documents. He worked to oversee the effort and recruit troops, among others from \u3010140\u2020Executive Outcomes\u3011, a former South African mercenary firm hired by several African governments during the 1990s to defeat violent rebellions in addition to protecting oil and diamond reserves. \n\nAs of January 2011, Prince was training a force of 2,000 Somalis for anti-piracy operations in the Gulf of Aden. The program was funded by several Arab countries, including the \u3010141\u2020United Arab Emirates\u3011 and backed by the United States. Prince&#x27;s spokesman, \u3010142\u2020Mark Corallo\u3011, said Prince had &quot;no financial role&quot; in the project and declined to answer any questions about Prince&#x27;s involvement. With Prince&#x27;s background and rather illustrious reputation, I think it&#x27;s quite possible that it might work.&quot;[ 37 ]\n\n### Private equity investor in Africa\n\n[\u3010143\u2020edit\u3011]\n\nPrince leads a private equity firm called Frontier Resource Group, and until April 13, 2021, he was also chairman of \u301090\u2020Frontier Services Group\u3011 Ltd, a Bermuda-incorporated logistics and transport company listed on the \u3010144\u2020Hong Kong Stock Exc", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[8, 2, 7, 9, 12]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "2d83f8fc-8547-432d-9898-d85410e3212b", "request_id": "8d71cd7a39500dfa-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "2d83f8fc-8547-432d-9898-d85410e3212b", "children": ["e9cbab1e-c480-4b78-b163-8633d1a6379c"]}, "e9cbab1e-c480-4b78-b163-8633d1a6379c": { "message": { "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729687319.01265, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["In 2024, Erik Prince remains an influential yet controversial figure. His connections to these groups highlight his influence in shaping radical views on handling international crises.\n\nAdditionally, Prince is under FBI investigation for alleged arms trafficking and support for Libyan warlord Khalifa Haftar, which involves potential violations of international arms embargoes\u30106\u2020source\u3011\u30107\u2020source\u3011\u30108\u2020source\u3011. \n\nHis activities span both legitimate and clandestine spheres, reinforcing his ongoing role in global military and security affairs."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 1018, "end_ix": 1028, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "FBI investigates Blackwater&#x27;s Erik Prince over alleged support for Haftar | The Libya Observer", "url": "https://libyaobserver.ly/news/fbi-investigates-blackwaters-erik-prince-over-alleged-support-haftar", "text": "  * \u301019\u2020Education\u3011 \n  * Multimedia\n\n    * \u301020\u2020Images\u3011 \n    * \u301021\u2020Videos\u3011 \n\n  * \u301022\u2020Print edition\u3011 \n\n  * Menu\n\nnewsbeat Drupal\n\nJust another Drupal site\n\n  * Search\n\nSearch\n\nCategory: \u30105\u2020News\u3011 \n\n# FBI investigates Blackwater&#x27;s Erik Prince over alleged support for Haftar\n\nby  \u301023\u2020SafaAlharathy\u3011 Sun, 18/08/2024 - 14:14\n\n  * \u301024\u2020Share\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011\n  * \u301025\u2020Tweet\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n[Image 0: fbi] \n\nThe FBI has launched an investigation into Erik Prince, the former head of the private security firm Blackwater and an ally of former US President Donald Trump, over his alleged involvement in illegal arms sales and money laundering. The probe is also examining Prince\u2019s connections with foreign intelligence and military entities, including his reported support for rogue military commander Khalifa Haftar.\n\nAccording to the \u201cWashington Babylon\u201d newspaper, the investigation focuses on three main areas. Firstly, Prince is suspected of facilitating the illegal transfer of weapons to Haftar, a violation of the international arms embargo on Libya. Prince is alleged to have played a significant role in assisting Haftar during his 2019 attempt to overthrow Libya\u2019s internationally recognized government.\n\nThe investigation also scrutinizes whether Prince\u2019s laundered money is linked to his support for Haftar. The United Nations has estimated the cost of Prince\u2019s assistance to Haftar at $80 million, with much of the funding reportedly originating from the United Arab Emirates.\n\nAdditionally, the FBI is exploring the broader relationship between Prince and Haftar, particularly Prince\u2019s involvement in providing military support and operational planning for Haftar\u2019s forces.\n\nTags: \u301026\u2020Khalifa Haftar\u3011 \u301027\u2020blackwater\u3011 \u301028\u2020mercenaries\u3011 \n\n### Read Also:\n\n\u301029\u2020 \u3011  \u30105\u2020News\u3011\n\n#### \u301029\u2020Amnesty "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1028, "end_ix": 1038, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Off Leash: Inside the Secret, Global, Far-Right Group Chat   | The New Republic", "url": "https://newrepublic.com/article/182008/erik-prince-secret-global-group-chat-off-leash", "text": "\nOff Leash was still active as of Wednesday, though I expect it won\u2019t be, at least in its current form, for much longer, given that the conversation Wednesday included much discussion about their security being breached, which became evident after I reached out to participants for comment. Fortunately, I obtained details about a large slice of the chat group\u2019s discussions over the past six months. Here\u2019s some of what they discussed.\n\nSolving the Middle East Crisis: Nukes, Napalm, and Other \u201cExtreme Measures\u201d\n\nOff Leash was launched less than two months after Israel commenced its assault on Gaza following Hamas\u2019s deadly October 7 attack on Israel, and that topic has been one of the group chat\u2019s main concerns since it was established by Prince on December 2. Five days later, Omer Laviv, an executive with the Mer Group, a private security company with many former Israeli intelligence officials in its senior ranks, posted \u301016\u2020a story\u2020www.thetimes.co.uk\u3011 to the group that ran two days earlier in The Times of London and reported Prince had been seeking to sell the Israel Defense Forces equipment for a plan he\u2019d devised to flood Hamas tunnels with seawater.\n\n\u201cI was involved,\u201d remarked Moti Kahana, the Israeli American businessman who runs GDC, the firm where Off Leash member Stuart Seldowitz previously worked. Kahana pointedly added that at least one part of The Times\u2019 story was false\u2014for example, Prince had offered to donate the equipment, not sell it, he said.\n\n\u201cWhy do you expect accuracy from journalists?\u201d retorted Laviv, who during the Trump administration retained 27 U.S. lobbyists and consultants to run a $9.5 million lobbying campaign on behalf of President Joseph Kabila, the corrupt, brutal leader of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who used surveillance equipment supplied by the Mer Group to monitor his regime\u2019s opponents. Among those Laviv involved were Rudy Giuliani, Trump\u2019s former personal lawyer, fixer, and dirt-digger, and Robert Stryk, whose clients have included Saudi Arabia and El Salvador\u2019s state intelligence agency under crypto-fascist President Nayib Bukele.\n\nYudelson, who also reportedly partnered with Prince in an attempt to buy weapons for resale from Belarus dictator Aleksandr Lukashenko (\u301017\u2020whom the two men praised for bringing \u201cpeace, stability, and prosperity to your country\u2020matthewcole.substack.com\u3011\u201d), predicted the tunnel-flooding proposal would be shot down by the \u201cIsraeli left,\u201d a force he labeled the country\u2019s \u201cbiggest enemy,\u201d ahead of Hamas and Iran, over concerns about the environmental impact in Gaza. \u201cWho gives a shit about that,\u201d Yudelson posted to the group. \u201cIf it was up to me \u2026 I would flood them with Napalm! I would burn all those bastards, and have everything above ground, everything left of Gaza, collapse into this fiery hell pit and burn!\u201d\n\nEven that was deemed to be insufficiently hawkish for some Off Leash participants. In a lengthy tirade on February 14, Tzvi Lev, who formerly worked in Israel\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said it was rare to see a people as \u201ctwisted\u201d as Palestinians, whose culture \u201cworships death and bloodshed.\u201d The only solution, he wrote, was to \u201ccompletely uproot the radical Islamic Palestinian nationalism,\u201d which was possible to do based on the historical precedent of Japan, which \u201cwent from being nuked twice to one of the world\u2019s strongest economies within two decades.\u201d Dropping nuclear weapons on what\u2019s left of densely populated Gaza, which is roughly the size of Detroit, would be a war crime and kill huge numbers of civilians.\n\nYoav Goldhorn, \u301018\u2020the former Israeli intelligence officer\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, also cited \u201cfucking nukes in Japan\u201d as an appropriate remedy to the Palestinian problem. Sadly, wrote Goldhorn, whose LinkedIn profile says he has \u201ca passion for strategic planning,\u201d there was no one in the Israeli government with \u201cthe balls nor vision to go all those extra miles.\u201d\n\nIran: Off Leash\u2019s Public Enemy No. 1 \n\nIt was hard to keep track of all the wars, invasions, covert operations, coups, and assassinations Off Leash members favored. One region ripe for a bit of good old-fashioned Western intervention was Africa, which was described as a \u201cpot about to boil over\u201d by \u301019\u2020Emma Priestley\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011, who posts as \u201cCustomer\u201d in the group chat and is the \u301019\u2020CEO of GoldStone Resources Limited\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011 in Jersey, the English Channel island that is one of the world\u2019s most popular offshore secrecy havens. China would have to be taken down a peg as well, particularly as Biden wasn\u2019t going to stop the country \u201cfrom doing a damn thing,\u201d and indeed he would pave the way for it to do \u201cwhatever it is they want to accomplish,\u201d posted Randy Couture, the former UFC heavyweight champion and actor who had the role of arsonist and killer Jason Duclair in the TV series Hawaii Five-0 and starred in the 2011 movie Setup with 50 Cent and Bruce Willis.\n\nBut the No. 1 target on Off Leash\u2019s hit list, by orders of magnitude, was Iran. \u201cFollow the source of evil,\u201d wrote Montana Congressman Ryan Zinke, who served as interior secretary under Trump. \u201cHamas. Hezbollah. Houthis. Iran is the center of gravity.\u201d\n\n\u201cZinke is right,\u201d agreed Tennessee Congressman Mark Green of the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nYemen\u2019s Houthi rebels", "pub_date": null, "extra": "\n\u301021\u2020Opinion\u3011\n\n\u301022\u2020World\u3011\n\n\u301023\u2020Sponsored\u3011\n\n[Image 4: search]\n\nMORE\n\n[Image 5: search]\n\n\u30102\u2020Politics\u3011[Image 6: Reserved.\n\n\u30101\u2020Home\u3011\n\n/\n\n\u301022\u2020World\u3011\n\n# Erik Prince says China likely to attack Taiwan in 2024 \n\nXi Jinping must feel &#x27;door is wide open&#x27; amid declining US credibility under Biden administration, says former Blackwater chair \n\nDec. 31, 2023 16:58\n\n[Image 21: Erik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) ]\n\nErik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) \n\n38154 \n\nTAIPEI (Taiwan News) \u2014 In a video interview on the U.K.\u2019s GB News filmed on Thursday (Dec. 28), Erik Prince, a military contractor known for founding the Blackwater organization, said he expects China to target Taiwan militarily in the spring of 2024.\n\nPrince, a military strategist and former U.S. Navy Seal, was being \u301027\u2020interviewed\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011 by Jacob Rees-Mogg about U.S. foreign policy setbacks under the Biden administration and the pressures faced by the U.S. military around the world. Prince said that amid declining U.S. credibility abroad, Chinese leader Xi Jinping (\u7fd2\u8fd1\u5e73) may try to \u201cbluster his way\u201d into a takeover of Taiwan, saying that \u201cit must feel like the door is wide open for them to do whatever it is they want to do.\u201d\n\nPrince\u2019s comments came one day after Xi Jinping, speaking at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, resolutely vowed to stop anyone from \u201cmaking Taiwan secede from China,\u201d calling \u301028\u2020unification\u3011 an \u201cinevitable trend.\u201d\n\nIn Prince\u2019s remarks, he criticized the U.S. \u201cinability to finish properly in Iraq and Afghanistan,\u201d which he credits for the increase of military threats across the world that have taken shape under the Biden administration. In addition to ongoing conflicts involving Ukraine and Israel, Prince also mentioned escalating conflicts in the wider Middle East, which now include attacks by Houthi rebels targeting shipping vessels in the Red Sea.\n\nSpeaking about a timeline for a potential attack by China on Taiwan, Prince said May or June 2024 is a likely window for Beijing to begin cross-strait naval operations. &quot;If they are going to take Taiwan by force, I would predict that they are going to do something this spring,&quot; Prince said, as reported by \u301029\u2020GB News\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011.\n\nThe day after Prince made his prediction on GB News, China announced a shakeup in its military command. With only two weeks before Taiwan&#x27;s elections, Beijing appointed PLAN \u301030\u2020Admiral Dong Jun\u3011 as its newest Minister of National Defense.\n\nAfter leaving Blackwater and selling the company in 2010, Erik Prince\u2019s connections to CIA training programs were revealed in 2013. Around 2014, Prince became the chairman of a private security and logistics firm called the Frontier Services Group, a Chinese-owned company based in Hong Kong and involved in private security contract work in Africa.\n\nPrince stepped down as chairman of the Frontier Services Group in April 2021 but is still the head of a similar organization called the Frontier Resource Group, which has almost no online footprint as of publication.\n\n\u301031\u2020# Chinese invasion of Taiwan\u3011\u301032\u2020# Biden Administration\u3011\u301033\u2020# Erik Prince\u3011\u301034\u2020# Xi Jinping\u3011\n\n# Related Articles\n\n* * *\n\n\u301035\u2020Ex-Australia PM calls for effective deterrent against China\u2019s threats to annex Taiwan Oct. 22, 2024 14:56\u3011\u301036\u2020Harris says Taiwan &#x27;has right to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 17, 2024 10:41\u3011\u301037\u2020Trump claims China will not invade Taiwan if he is elected Oct. 16, 2024 16:43\u3011\u301038\u2020Former AIT chair says Article 8 of China\u2019s Anti-Secession Law is time bomb Oct. 16, 2024 13:43\u3011\u301039\u2020Poll shows 36% of Americans support sending troops to defend Taiwan Oct. 9, 2024 16:26\u3011\u301040\u2020Harris backs &#x27;Taiwan&#x27;s ability to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 8, 2024 14:27\u3011\n\n# MOST READ\n\n* * *\n\n\u301041\u2020Harvard punishes Taiwanese American student for disrupting Chinese ambassador\u3011\u301042\u2020Tropical Storm Trami forecast to steer south of Taiwan\u3011\u301043\u2020Tropi", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source", "cloud_doc_url": null}}}], "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u30106\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1018, "end_idx": 1028, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "FBI investigates Blackwater&#x27;s Erik Prince over alleged support for Haftar | The Libya Observer", "url": "https://libyaobserver.ly/news/fbi-investigates-blackwaters-erik-prince-over-alleged-support-haftar", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "  * \u301019\u2020Education\u3011 \n  * Multimedia\n\n    * \u301020\u2020Images\u3011 \n    * \u301021\u2020Videos\u3011 \n\n  * \u301022\u2020Print edition\u3011 \n\n  * Menu\n\nnewsbeat Drupal\n\nJust another Drupal site\n\n  * Search\n\nSearch\n\nCategory: \u30105\u2020News\u3011 \n\n# FBI investigates Blackwater&#x27;s Erik Prince over alleged support for Haftar\n\nby  \u301023\u2020SafaAlharathy\u3011 Sun, 18/08/2024 - 14:14\n\n  * \u301024\u2020Share\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011\n  * \u301025\u2020Tweet\u2020twitter.com\u3011\n\n[Image 0: fbi] \n\nThe FBI has launched an investigation into Erik Prince, the former head of the private security firm Blackwater and an ally of former US President Donald Trump, over his alleged involvement in illegal arms sales and money laundering. The probe is also examining Prince\u2019s connections with foreign intelligence and military entities, including his reported support for rogue military commander Khalifa Haftar.\n\nAccording to the \u201cWashington Babylon\u201d newspaper, the investigation focuses on three main areas. Firstly, Prince is suspected of facilitating the illegal transfer of weapons to Haftar, a violation of the international arms embargo on Libya. Prince is alleged to have played a significant role in assisting Haftar during his 2019 attempt to overthrow Libya\u2019s internationally recognized government.\n\nThe investigation also scrutinizes whether Prince\u2019s laundered money is linked to his support for Haftar. The United Nations has estimated the cost of Prince\u2019s assistance to Haftar at $80 million, with much of the funding reportedly originating from the United Arab Emirates.\n\nAdditionally, the FBI is exploring the broader relationship between Prince and Haftar, particularly Prince\u2019s involvement in providing military support and operational planning for Haftar\u2019s forces.\n\nTags: at least in its current form, for much longer, given that the conversation Wednesday included much discussion about their security being breached, which became evident after I reached out to participants for comment. Fortunately, I obtained details about a large slice of the chat group\u2019s discussions over the past six months. Here\u2019s some of what they discussed.\n\nSolving the Middle East Crisis: Nukes, Napalm, and Other \u201cExtreme Measures\u201d\n\nOff Leash was launched less than two months after Israel commenced its assault on Gaza following Hamas\u2019s deadly October 7 attack on Israel, and that topic has been one of the group chat\u2019s main concerns since it was established by Prince on December 2. Five days later, Omer Laviv, an executive with the Mer Group, a private security company with many former Israeli intelligence officials in its senior ranks, posted \u301016\u2020a story\u2020www.thetimes.co.uk\u3011 to the group that ran two days earlier in The Times of London and reported Prince had been seeking to sell the Israel Defense Forces equipment for a plan he\u2019d devised to flood Hamas tunnels with seawater.\n\n\u201cI was involved,\u201d remarked Moti Kahana, the Israeli American businessman who runs GDC, the firm where Off Leash member Stuart Seldowitz previously worked. Kahana pointedly added that at least one part of The Times\u2019 story was false\u2014for example, Prince had offered to donate the equipment, not sell it, he said.\n\n\u201cWhy do you expect accuracy from journalists?\u201d retorted Laviv, who during the Trump administration retained 27 U.S. lobbyists and consultants to run a $9.5 million lobbying campaign on behalf of President Joseph Kabila, the corrupt, brutal leader of the Democratic Republic of Congo, who used surveillance equipment supplied by the Mer Group to monitor his regime\u2019s opponents. Among those Laviv involved were Rudy Giuliani, Trump\u2019s former personal lawyer, fixer, and dirt-digger, and Robert Stryk, whose clients have included Saudi Arabia and El Salvador\u2019s state intelligence agency under crypto-fascist President Nayib Bukele.\n\nYudelson, who also reportedly partnered with Prince in an attempt to buy weapons for resale from Belarus dictator Aleksandr Lukashenko (\u301017\u2020whom the two men praised for bringing \u201cpeace, stability, and prosperity to your country\u2020matthewcole.substack.com\u3011\u201d), predicted the tunnel-flooding proposal would be shot down by the \u201cIsraeli left,\u201d a force he labeled the country\u2019s \u201cbiggest enemy,\u201d ahead of Hamas and Iran, over concerns about the environmental impact in Gaza. \u201cWho gives a shit about that,\u201d Yudelson posted to the group. \u201cIf it was up to me \u2026 I would flood them with Napalm! I would burn all those bastards, and have everything above ground, everything left of Gaza, collapse into this fiery hell pit and burn!\u201d\n\nEven that was deemed to be insufficiently hawkish for some Off Leash participants. In a lengthy tirade on February 14, Tzvi Lev, who formerly worked in Israel\u2019s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, said it was rare to see a people as \u201ctwisted\u201d as Palestinians, whose culture \u201cworships death and bloodshed.\u201d The only solution, he wrote, was to \u201ccompletely uproot the radical Islamic Palestinian nationalism,\u201d which was possible to do based on the historical precedent of Japan, which \u201cwent from being nuked twice to one of the world\u2019s strongest economies within two decades.\u201d Dropping nuclear weapons on what\u2019s left of densely populated Gaza, which is roughly the size of Detroit, would be a war crime and kill huge numbers of civilians.\n\nYoav Goldhorn, \u301018\u2020the former Israeli intelligence officer\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, also cited \u201cfucking nukes in Japan\u201d as an appropriate remedy to the Palestinian problem. Sadly, wrote Goldhorn, whose LinkedIn profile says he has \u201ca passion for strategic planning,\u201d there was no one in the Israeli government with \u201cthe balls nor vision to go all those extra miles.\u201d\n\nIran: Off Leash\u2019s Public Enemy No. 1 \n\nIt was hard to keep track of all the wars, invasions, covert operations, coups, and assassinations Off Leash members favored. One region ripe for a bit of good old-fashioned Western intervention was Africa, which was described as a \u201cpot about to boil over\u201d by \u301019\u2020Emma Priestley\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011, who posts as \u201cCustomer\u201d in the group chat and is the \u301019\u2020CEO of GoldStone Resources Limited\u2020otp.investis.com\u3011 in Jersey, the English Channel island that is one of the world\u2019s most popular offshore secrecy havens. China would have to be taken down a peg as well, particularly as Biden wasn\u2019t going to stop the country \u201cfrom doing a damn thing,\u201d and indeed he would pave the way for it to do \u201cwhatever it is they want to accomplish,\u201d posted Randy Couture, the former UFC heavyweight champion and actor who had the role of arsonist and killer Jason Duclair in the TV series Hawaii Five-0 and starred in the 2011 movie Setup with 50 Cent and Bruce Willis.\n\nBut the No. 1 target on Off Leash\u2019s hit list, by orders of magnitude, was Iran. \u201cFollow the source of evil,\u201d wrote Montana Congressman Ryan Zinke, who served as interior secretary under Trump. \u201cHamas. Hezbollah. Houthis. Iran is the center of gravity.\u201d\n\n\u201cZinke is right,\u201d agreed Tennessee Congressman Mark Green of the House Freedom Caucus.\n\nYemen\u2019s Houthi rebels"}, {"matched_text": Reserved.\n\n\u30101\u2020Home\u3011\n\n/\n\n\u301022\u2020World\u3011\n\n# Erik Prince says China likely to attack Taiwan in 2024 \n\nXi Jinping must feel &#x27;door is wide open&#x27; amid declining US credibility under Biden administration, says former Blackwater chair \n\nDec. 31, 2023 16:58\n\n[Image 21: Erik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) ]\n\nErik Prince in New York City, November 2019. (Reuters photo) \n\n38154 \n\nTAIPEI (Taiwan News) \u2014 In a video interview on the U.K.\u2019s GB News filmed on Thursday (Dec. 28), Erik Prince, a military contractor known for founding the Blackwater organization, said he expects China to target Taiwan militarily in the spring of 2024.\n\nPrince, a military strategist and former U.S. Navy Seal, was being \u301027\u2020interviewed\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011 by Jacob Rees-Mogg about U.S. foreign policy setbacks under the Biden administration and the pressures faced by the U.S. military around the world. Prince said that amid declining U.S. credibility abroad, Chinese leader Xi Jinping (\u7fd2\u8fd1\u5e73) may try to \u201cbluster his way\u201d into a takeover of Taiwan, saying that \u201cit must feel like the door is wide open for them to do whatever it is they want to do.\u201d\n\nPrince\u2019s comments came one day after Xi Jinping, speaking at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, resolutely vowed to stop anyone from \u201cmaking Taiwan secede from China,\u201d calling \u301028\u2020unification\u3011 an \u201cinevitable trend.\u201d\n\nIn Prince\u2019s remarks, he criticized the U.S. \u201cinability to finish properly in Iraq and Afghanistan,\u201d which he credits for the increase of military threats across the world that have taken shape under the Biden administration. In addition to ongoing conflicts involving Ukraine and Israel, Prince also mentioned escalating conflicts in the wider Middle East, which now include attacks by Houthi rebels targeting shipping vessels in the Red Sea.\n\nSpeaking about a timeline for a potential attack by China on Taiwan, Prince said May or June 2024 is a likely window for Beijing to begin cross-strait naval operations. &quot;If they are going to take Taiwan by force, I would predict that they are going to do something this spring,&quot; Prince said, as reported by \u301029\u2020GB News\u2020www.gbnews.com\u3011.\n\nThe day after Prince made his prediction on GB News, China announced a shakeup in its military command. With only two weeks before Taiwan&#x27;s elections, Beijing appointed PLAN \u301030\u2020Admiral Dong Jun\u3011 as its newest Minister of National Defense.\n\nAfter leaving Blackwater and selling the company in 2010, Erik Prince\u2019s connections to CIA training programs were revealed in 2013. Around 2014, Prince became the chairman of a private security and logistics firm called the Frontier Services Group, a Chinese-owned company based in Hong Kong and involved in private security contract work in Africa.\n\nPrince stepped down as chairman of the Frontier Services Group in April 2021 but is still the head of a similar organization called the Frontier Resource Group, which has almost no online footprint as of publication.\n\n\u301031\u2020# Chinese invasion of Taiwan\u3011\u301032\u2020# Biden Administration\u3011\u301033\u2020# Erik Prince\u3011\u301034\u2020# Xi Jinping\u3011\n\n# Related Articles\n\n* * *\n\n\u301035\u2020Ex-Australia PM calls for effective deterrent against China\u2019s threats to annex Taiwan Oct. 22, 2024 14:56\u3011\u301036\u2020Harris says Taiwan &#x27;has right to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 17, 2024 10:41\u3011\u301037\u2020Trump claims China will not invade Taiwan if he is elected Oct. 16, 2024 16:43\u3011\u301038\u2020Former AIT chair says Article 8 of China\u2019s Anti-Secession Law is time bomb Oct. 16, 2024 13:43\u3011\u301039\u2020Poll shows 36% of Americans support sending troops to defend Taiwan Oct. 9, 2024 16:26\u3011\u301040\u2020Harris backs &#x27;Taiwan&#x27;s ability to defend itself&#x27; Oct. 8, 2024 14:27\u3011\n\n# MOST READ\n\n* * *\n\n\u301041\u2020Harvard punishes Taiwanese American student for disrupting Chinese ambassador\u3011\u301042\u2020Tropical Storm Trami forecast to steer south of Taiwan\u3011\u301043\u2020Tropi"}], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4o", "parent_id": "4678175a-6ced-49e9-8a45-f05ed4ccce02", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [200002]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "8d71cd7a39500dfa-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4678175a-6ced-49e9-8a45-f05ed4ccce02", "children": ["aaa26526-7874-4494-8d4d-bf8cd90a3b44"]}, "aaa26526-7874-4494-8d4d-bf8cd90a3b44": { "message": { "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729687407.377412, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["can you tell me the time?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"serialization_metadata": {"custom_symbol_offsets": []}, "request_id": "8d71d001c9370dfa-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "e9cbab1e-c480-4b78-b163-8633d1a6379c", "children": ["062ad643-5f96-43d0-ac9b-9ab93b7c1214"]}, "062ad643-5f96-43d0-ac9b-9ab93b7c1214": { "message": { "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729687412.551516, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The current time is 10:40 AM UTC on October 23, 2024. Unlike THC, which is known for its psychoactive properties that cause the &quot;high,&quot; THCv has been shown to have more subtle, and in some cases, opposing effects.\n\nKey points about THCv:\n\n1. **Appetite Suppression**: THCv is known for its potential to suppress appetite, which is the opposite of THC, which is often associated with increasing hunger (the &quot;munchies&quot;). This has sparked interest in THCv for weight management or obesity treatment.\n\n2. **Psychoactive Effects**: At low doses, THCv is not significantly psychoactive, meaning it doesn\u2019t cause a strong high. However, at higher doses, it can produce effects similar to THC, though they are often described as clearer-headed and shorter-lasting.\n\n3. **Potential Health Benefits**: Early research suggests THCv may have therapeutic potential in areas such as reducing insulin resistance in diabetes, managing anxiety, and possibly aiding in bone growth. It\u2019s also being studied for its anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective properties, which could make it useful in treating conditions like Parkinson&#x27;s disease.\n\n4. **Energy Boost and Focus**: Some users report that THCv provides an energizing and focusing effect, which differs from the more sedative qualities of certain THC-rich cannabis strains.\n\nTHCv is not as abundant as THC or CBD in most cannabis strains, but breeders are developing strains with higher THCv content due to its unique potential benefits."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

Convert the DOCX to PDF for reliable formatting\r\n    from fpdf import FPDF\r\n    \r\n    # Initialize PDF document\r\n    pdf = FPDF()\r\n    pdf.add_page()\r\n    pdf.set_font(&quot;Arial&quot;, size=12)\r\n    \r\n    # Load the DOCX content\r\n    doc = Document(resume_path)\r\n    content = []\r\n    for para in doc.paragraphs:\r\n        content.append(para.text)\r\n    \r\n    # Add content to PDF\r\n    for line in content:\r\n        pdf.cell(200, 10, txt=line, ln=True)\r\n    \r\n    # Save the PDF\r\n    pdf_output_path = &quot;/mnt/data/Alexis_Lindsay_Chronological_Final_Resume.pdf&quot;\r\n    pdf.output(pdf_output_path)\r\n    pdf_output_path\r\nelse:\r\n    &quot;The document path does not exist or the file was not found.&quot;"}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": false, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "content_references": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "26b1884c-2587-4070-b8ff-d3c380fd12ec", "request_id": "8d6406027bf959b3-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100265]}, "is_complete": true}, "recipient": "python", "channel": null}, "parent": "26b1884c-2587-4070-b8ff-d3c380fd12ec", "children": ["37234b92-3433-444b-9cda-78ec4ad89891"]}, "37234b92-3433-444b-9cda-78ec4ad89891": { "message": { "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "python", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1729542843.66181, "update_time": 1729542837.7301438, "content": {"content_type": "execution_output", "text": ""}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"is_complete": true, "aggregate_result": {"status": "success", "run_id": "30b8cb53-365a-44b9-8336-7a34aa0be27a", "start_time": 1729542837.4263232, "update_time": 1729542837.7301438, "code": "from docx import Document\r\nimport os\r\n\r\n# Define path for the resume file\r\nresume_path = &quot;/mnt/data/Alexis_Lindsay_Chronological_Final_Resume.docx&quot;\r\n\r\n# Check if the file exists\r\nif os.path.exists(resume_path):\r\n    # API definitions specify the requests that your skill code can handle.\r\n\r\nAs the user interacts with your skill, Alexa Conversations predicts the correct API based on the current dialog context. API definitions are analogous to intents in intent-based dialog models.\r\n\r\nGet Started\r\n\r\nTo get started with Alexa Conversations, you can step through a pet match skill-building tutorial, download the code for a pizza-ordering reference skill, or use an Alexa-hosted sample skill template that includes an Alexa Conversations skill configuration and back-end skill code.\r\nExample\r\nConsider a weather skill that has a GetWeather API that accepts two arguments (date and city) and returns a returnedWeather value that contains properties for cityName, date, highTemperature, and lowTemperature. To use this API in an Alexa Conversations skill, you must create an API definition for the GetWeather API when you configure your skill in the developer console.\r\n\r\nWhen you annotate dialogs for your skill, the API definitions are often what tie the user line and the Alexa line together. The following example shows what one dialog in your skill might be:\r\n\r\nUser: What&#x27;s the weather in Seattle tomorrow?\r\nAlexa: Tomorrow in Seattle, you can expect a high of 71 degrees and a low of 57 degrees.\r\n\r\nWhen you annotate this dialog, you associate both the user utterance group and the Alexa response with the GetWeather API definition. The user utterance group provides the inputs to the API, and the Alexa response formats the output of the API into Alexa TTS.\r\n\r\nAPI definitions, slot types, and responses\r\nWhen you define an API, you specify an API name, input arguments, and a return type. Because APIs tie into slot types and responses, keep in mind that you also must do the following:\r\n\r\nCreate slot types for any API arguments and return types that aren&#x27;t built-in types. For details, see Use Slot Types.\r\n\r\nFor example, if your weather skill returns the response, &quot;Tomorrow in Seattle, you can expect a high of 71 degrees and a low of 57 degrees,&quot; you might create a returnedWeather slot type that contains a city, date, high temperature, and low temperature. For details about slot types, see Use Slot Types in Alexa Conversations.\r\nCreate responses to define how Alexa responds to the user. For details, see Define Responses from Alexa for Alexa Conversations.\r\nAPI definitions and dialog acts\r\nEach API must have at least one dialog that uses the Request Args dialog act. You can&#x27;t simply have a dialog where the user provides your arguments as part of the initial utterance.\r\n\r\nAPI arguments\r\nFor higher API prediction accuracy, we recommend the following:\r\n\r\nFive or fewer arguments per API.\r\nDistinct types of arguments. For example, one argument of type AMAZON.NUMBER and another argument of type AMAZON.US_CITY typically performs better than two arguments that are both of type AMAZON.NUMBER.\r\nDefine an API\r\nYou define APIs to your skill in the developer console as follows.\r\n\r\n Important: If you don&#x27;t have all the information that you need to create the API definition, you can skip parts of the API definition and come back to them later. However, if you try to build the model, the build fails until you specify all of the required items.\r\nTo create an API definition\r\n\r\nLog in to the developer console, and then navigate to your Alexa Conversations skill.\r\nIn the left pane, click API Definitions.\r\nClick Add API Definition.\r\nEnter a name for the API.\r\nIf the API has arguments, do the following:\r\n\r\n Note: Alexa Conversations currently doesn&#x27;t support APIs that take multiple list arguments. (Each API can have at most one list argument.)\r\nUnder Arguments, click Add Argument.\r\nEnter the argument name and select a slot type.\r\nClick Add Argument to add other arguments, if applicable.\r\nUnder Return, select the slot type of the return value.\r\nFor details about slot types, see Use Slot Types in Alexa Conversations.\r\nIn the header bar, click Save.\r\nRelated topics\r\nDefine Responses from Alexa for Alexa Conversations\r\nAbout Alexa Conversations\r\nGet Started with Alexa Conversations\r\nWas this page helpful? \r\nYes\r\nNo\r\nProvide feedback\r\nLast updated: Nov 27, 2023\n\n\nCAN I USE THIS AND MAKE THE API THEOPEN API AND THE ARGUMENT COULD BE A QUESTION? Here\u2019s how you can set it up:\n\n### Step-by-Step Overview:\n\n1. **Define the API** in the Alexa Developer Console:\n   - You\u2019ll create an API definition that connects to **The Open API** or another external API.\n   - The argument, which could be a **user&#x27;s question**, will be processed as input, and the API will return the relevant data.\n\n2. **Create Slot Types**:\n   - Since Alexa uses slot types to understand and process input, you&#x27;ll need to create custom slot types that map to the API&#x27;s parameters.\n   - For example, if the user&#x27;s question asks for &quot;weather in Seattle tomorrow,&quot; you\u2019ll need to create a slot type for cities (`AMAZON.US_CITY`) and dates (`AMAZON.DATE`).\n\n3. **Handle the Question as an Argument**:\n   - You can configure the argument to be the user&#x27;s question or part of the conversation. For example, you can take an open-ended question like &quot;What is the weather tomorrow in Seattle?&quot; and pass the relevant data (city, date) to **The Open API**.\n   - Make sure to associate the question with the right API and return the correct response type (i.e., formatted weather data).\n\n### Example Setup for Weather Query:\n\n- **API Definition**:\n  - **API Name**: `GetWeatherAPI`\n  - **Arguments**:\n    - `city` (Slot type: `AMAZON.US_CITY`)\n    - `date` (Slot type: `AMAZON.DATE`)\n  - **Return Type**:\n    - `returnedWeather` (a custom slot type that contains `city`, `date`, `highTemperature`, and `lowTemperature`)\n\n- **Interaction Flow**:\n   1. **User Question**: &quot;What&#x27;s the weather in Seattle tomorrow?&quot;\n   2. **Alexa Conversation**:\n      - Alexa identifies the intent (weather query) and matches the API (`GetWeatherAPI`).\n      - The inputs (city: &quot;Seattle&quot;, date: &quot;tomorrow&quot;) are passed to the API.\n   3. **API Response**:\n      - The API (The Open API) returns data for &quot;Seattle&quot; and &quot;tomorrow.&quot;\n   4. **Alexa Response**:\n      - Alexa formats the response: &quot;Tomorrow in Seattle, the high will be 71 degrees and the low will be 57 degrees.&quot;\n\n### Key Considerations:\n- **API Design**: When integrating The Open API, ensure your skill\u2019s backend can process the request and call The Open API, passing along the necessary parameters (like the user&#x27;s question).\n- **User Input as a Question**: Yes, you can pass open-ended questions as input, but you\u2019ll need to map relevant slots from that question to the API arguments. Use dialog management to capture and clarify the user\u2019s intent if needed.\n- **Error Handling**: Plan for cases where the API might not have enough data or when the user&#x27;s input is ambiguous (e.g., &quot;What is the weather?&quot; without a city or date).\n\n### Example of an API Definition for Open API:\n\n1. **API Name**: `TheOpenAPI`\n2. **Arguments**:\n   - `question` (Slot type: `AMAZON.SearchQuery`) \u2013 which can capture the user&#x27;s question.\n3. **Return**: You\u2019ll need to specify the return slot type based on the kind of response you expect from The Open API (e.g., text or formatted data).\n4. **Backend Code**: Ensure your backend Lambda function processes the `question`, calls The Open API, and then returns a response formatted for Alexa.\n\nBy following this setup, you can create an Alexa skill using Alexa Conversations to call external APIs like The Open API and handle user questions as arguments. Let me know if you need further help with the configuration or coding!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

The Open API will provide a response under the specific constraint (like 1000 characters or less), which Alexa will then vocalize.\n\n### 2. **Steps to Build the Skill**:\n\n#### A. **Skill Design in Alexa Conversations**:\n1. **Create the API Definition**:\n   - **API Name**: `OpenAPIWeatherQuery`\n   - **Argument**: \n     - `question` (Type: `AMAZON.SearchQuery`) \u2013 this captures the entire user query, such as &quot;What&#x27;s the weather tomorrow in Seattle?&quot;\n   - **Return Type**: A custom slot that will hold the Open API response.\n     - You can define a return type like `response` which will be the formatted text that the Open API sends back (i.e., the weather information).\n\n#### B. **Interaction Flow**:\n   1. **User Input**: &quot;What&#x27;s the weather like tomorrow in Seattle?&quot;\n   2. **Alexa&#x27;s Action**: \n      - Alexa recognizes the intent and extracts the entire user query as `question`. \n      - Alexa sends the user query to **The Open API** using the custom API (`OpenAPIWeatherQuery`) you defined.\n   3. **API Call**:\n      - The backend service (via Lambda function or another backend) receives the user query, sends it to **The Open API**, and retrieves a weather response (formatted to be under 1000 characters).\n   4. **Alexa Response**:\n      - Alexa receives the response and speaks it aloud to the user.\n      - Skill ends.\n\n#### C. **Backend Logic in AWS Lambda**:\n   - **Function**: Your Lambda function needs to accept the user input (the question), forward it to The Open API, and process the response.\n   - **Request Flow**: \n     - The function will take the `question` (e.g., &quot;What&#x27;s the weather tomorrow in Seattle?&quot;), use it to call The Open API, and retrieve the formatted weather response.\n     - Limit the response size to 1000 characters or format it accordingly in your Lambda function.\n   \n   - **Lambda Code Example (Node.js)**:\n     ```javascript\n     const axios = require(&#x27;axios&#x27;);\n\n     exports.handler = async function (event) {\n         try {\n             const userQuery = event.request.intent.slots.question.value;\n             \n             // Make a call to The Open API (replace with actual API endpoint)\n             const apiResponse = await axios.post(&#x27;https://api.theopenapi.com/weather&#x27;, {\n                 query: userQuery,\n                 maxLength: 1000  // Limiting the response to 1000 characters\n             });\n             \n             const weatherResponse = apiResponse.data.response;\n             \n             // Return the response to Alexa\n             return {\n                 version: &#x27;1.0&#x27;,\n                 response: {\n                     outputSpeech: {\n                         type: &#x27;PlainText&#x27;,\n                         text: weatherResponse\n                     },\n                     shouldEndSession: true\n                 }\n             };\n         } catch (error) {\n             console.error(error);\n             return {\n                 version: &#x27;1.0&#x27;,\n                 response: {\n                     outputSpeech: {\n                         type: &#x27;PlainText&#x27;,\n                         text: &#x27;I am having trouble getting the weather information right now. Please try again later.&#x27;\n                     },\n                     shouldEndSession: true\n                 }\n             };\n         }\n     };\n     ```\n\n#### D. **Configuring the API**:\n- In **Alexa Developer Console**, go to **API Definitions** and define the `OpenAPIWeatherQuery` as described earlier.\n- Make sure the argument (question) is passed correctly from Alexa to your backend.\n\n### 3. **Summary of Steps**:\n1. **API Definition**: Create the API in Alexa Conversations, capturing the user question as an argument.\n2. **Lambda Function**: Build the backend logic (using AWS Lambda) to process the user input, call The Open API, and return a response.\n3. **API Call**: The Lambda function will handle the API call to The Open API, retrieve the result, and format it to be 1000 characters or less.\n4. **Alexa Response**: The response from The Open API is passed back to Alexa, and Alexa speaks it to the user.\n5. **Session End**: Once Alexa delivers the information, the skill session ends.\n\nThis setup allows Alexa to dynamically query The Open API with the user\u2019s question, retrieve the response, and speak it as part of the Alexa Conversations framework. If you need more assistance with any specific part of the setup, let me know!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

All Rights Reserved.\n * SPDX-License-Identifier: LicenseRef-.amazon.com.-AmznSL-1.0\n *\n * Licensed under the Amazon Software License (the &quot;License&quot;).\n * You may not use this file except in compliance with the License.\n * A copy of the License is located at\n *\n * http://aws.amazon.com/asl/\n *\n * or in the &quot;license&quot; file accompanying this file. This file is distributed\n * on an &quot;AS IS&quot; BASIS, WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either\n * express or implied. See the License for the specific language governing\n * permissions and limitations under the License.\n **/\n\nconst Alexa = require(&#x27;ask-sdk-core&#x27;);\nconst util = require(&#x27;./util&#x27;);\n\n/**\n * API Handler for RecordColor API\n *\n * @param handlerInput\n * @returns API response object\n *\n * See https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/docs/alexa/conversations/handle-api-calls.html\n */\nconst RecordColorApiHandler = {\n    canHandle(handlerInput) {\n        return util.isApiRequest(handlerInput, &#x27;RecordColor&#x27;);\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput) {\n        console.log(&quot;Api Request [RecordColor]: &quot;, JSON.stringify(handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request, null, 2));\n        // First get our request entity and grab the color passed in the API call\n        const args = util.getApiArguments(handlerInput);\n        const color = args.color;\n        // Store the favorite color in the session\n        const sessionAttributes = handlerInput.attributesManager.getSessionAttributes();\n        sessionAttributes.favoriteColor = color;\n\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n            .withApiResponse({\n                color: color\n            })\n            .withShouldEndSession(false)\n            .getResponse();\n    }\n}\n\nconst IntroToAlexaConversationsButtonEventHandler = {\n    canHandle(handlerInput) {\n        console.log(JSON.stringify(handlerInput.requestEnvelope));\n        return Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &#x27;Alexa.Presentation.APL.UserEvent&#x27;\n            &amp;&amp; handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request.arguments[0] === &#x27;SetFavoriteColor&#x27;;\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput) {\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n            .addDirective({\n                type: &#x27;Dialog.DelegateRequest&#x27;,\n                target: &#x27;AMAZON.Conversations&#x27;,\n                period: {\n                    until: &#x27;EXPLICIT_RETURN&#x27;\n                },\n                updatedRequest: {\n                    type: &#x27;Dialog.InputRequest&#x27;,\n                    input: {\n                        name: &#x27;SpecifyFavoriteColor&#x27;,\n                        slots: {\n                            &#x27;color&#x27;: {\n                                name: &#x27;color&#x27;,\n                                value: handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request.arguments[1]\n                            }\n                        }\n                    }\n                }\n            })\n            .getResponse();\n    }\n}\n\n/**\n * API Handler for GetFavoriteColor API\n *\n * @param handlerInput\n * @returns API response object\n *\n * See https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/docs/alexa/conversations/handle-api-calls.html\n */\nconst GetFavoriteColorApiHandler = {\n    canHandle(handlerInput) {\n        return util.isApiRequest(handlerInput, &#x27;GetFavoriteColor&#x27;);\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput) {\n        console.log(&quot;Api Request [GetFavoriteColor]: &quot;, JSON.stringify(handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request, null, 2));\n\n        // Get the favorite color from the session\n        const sessionAttributes = handlerInput.attributesManager.getSessionAttributes();\n        if (sessionAttributes.favoriteColor) {\n            var color = sessionAttributes.favoriteColor;\n        }\n\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n            .withApiResponse({\n                color: color\n            })\n            .withShouldEndSession(false)\n            .getResponse();\n    }\n}\n/**\n * FallbackIntentHandler - Handle all other requests to the skill\n *\n * @param handlerInput\n * @returns response\n *\n * See https://developer.amazon.com/en-US/docs/alexa/conversations/handle-api-calls.html\n */\nconst FallbackIntentHandler = {\n    canHandle(handlerInput) {\n        const request = handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request;\n        return request.type === &#x27;IntentRequest&#x27; &amp;&amp; request.intent.name !== &#x27;GetFavoriteColorApiHandler&#x27; &amp;&amp; request.intent.name !== &#x27;RecordColorApiHandler&#x27;;\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput) {\n        const intentName = handlerInput.requestEnvelope.request.intent.name;\n        console.log(&#x27;In catch all intent handler. Intent invoked: &#x27; + intentName);\n        const speechOutput = &quot;Hmm, I&#x27;m not sure. You can tell me your favorite color or ask me what your favorite color is. What would you like to do&quot;;\n\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n            .speak(speechOutput)\n            .reprompt(speechOutput)\n            .getResponse();\n    },\n};\nconst SessionEndedRequestHandler = {\n    canHandle(handlerInput) {\n        return Alexa.getRequestType(handlerInput.requestEnvelope) === &#x27;SessionEndedRequest&#x27;;\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput) {\n        // Any cleanup logic goes here.\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder.getResponse();\n    }\n};\n// Generic error handling to capture any syntax or routing errors. If you receive an error\n// stating the request handler chain is not found, you have not implemented a handler for\n// the intent being invoked or included it in the skill builder below.\nconst ErrorHandler = {\n    canHandle() {\n        return true;\n    },\n    handle(handlerInput, error) {\n        console.log(`~~~~ Error handled: ${error.stack}`);\n        const speakOutput = `Sorry, I had trouble doing what you asked. Please try again.`;\n\n        return handlerInput.responseBuilder\n            .speak(speakOutput)\n            .reprompt(speakOutput)\n            .getResponse();\n    }\n};\n// *****************************************************************************\n// These simple interceptors just log the incoming and outgoing request bodies to assist in debugging.\n\nconst LogRequestInterceptor = {\n    process(handlerInput) {\n        console.log(`REQUEST ENVELOPE = ${JSON.stringify(handlerInput.requestEnvelope)}`);\n    },\n};\n\nconst LogResponseInterceptor = {\n    process(handlerInput, response) {\n        console.log(`RESPONSE = ${JSON.stringify(response)}`);\n    },\n};\n// The SkillBuilder acts as the entry point for your skill, routing all request and response\n// payloads to the handlers above. Make sure any new handlers or interceptors you&#x27;ve\n// defined are included below. The order matters - they&#x27;re processed top to bottom.\nexports.handler = Alexa.SkillBuilders.custom()\n    .addErrorHandlers(ErrorHandler)\n    .addRequestInterceptors(LogRequestInterceptor)\n    .addResponseInterceptors(LogResponseInterceptor)\n    .addRequestHandlers(\n        RecordColorApiHandler,\n        GetFavoriteColorApiHandler,\n        IntroToAlexaConversationsButtonEventHandler,\n        FallbackIntentHandler,\n        SessionEndedRequestHandler\n    )\n    .withCustomUserAgent(&#x27;reference-skills/intro-to-alexa-conversations/v1&#x27;)\n    .lambda();\n\n\ncAN YOU GIVE ME THE CODE TOMAKE MY SKILL WORK?
